Wear sunscreen when outside due to sensitivity. Monitor for dryness or irritation. If needed, consider adding a topical antibiotic such as clindamycin or erythromycin.

Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling in toes.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Michelle is a 34-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of a right knee injury. She was skiing in Vermont last weekend when she caught her ski coming off the lift and fell, resulting in a popping sensation in her knee. She was unable to bear weight and had to be taken down the hill by the ski patrol. She reports pain on the outside of her knee and difficulty with flexion and extension. She denies any numbness or tingling in her toes and can feel them normally.  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient reports a personal history of being a very active mother of twins.  SOCIAL HISTORY  Patient is married and her husband works a job that requires him to be away from home often.  MEDICATIONS  Patient is taking ibuprofen for pain.  PHYSICAL EXAM  • Heart: Heart sounds in a nice regular rate and rhythm, no murmur. • Lungs: Lungs are nice and clear to auscultation. • Right Knee: Edema and effusion over the right knee, pain to palpation of the right lateral knee, decreased flexion and extension, positive Lachman sign, palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulse, no leg edema in the ankle.  ASSESSMENT  The patient has a right knee injury with pain on the outside of the knee and decreased flexion and extension. The patient has a positive Lachman sign and palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulse.  PLAN  The patient will continue taking ibuprofen for pain relief. The patient will be placed in a brace to help support the knee. An MRI will be ordered to confirm the physical exam findings and to rule out any other structures that may have been damaged in the accident. The patient will be advised to avoid any strenuous activities until the MRI results are available.

Results

Ibuprofen is prescribed for pain relief and a brace is recommended to provide support. Physical therapy is recommended to help with range of motion and strengthening of the knee. Surgery may be necessary to repair the ACL and meniscus tears.

Assessment

He will continue to take ibuprofen as needed for pain relief and will wear the knee brace as prescribed. He will also avoid any activities that cause pain or discomfort.

Subjective

Neurological exam is within normal limits.

Exam

• Musculoskeletal: Normal range of motion in all joints. No clubbing, cyanosis, or edema. • Cardiovascular: Normal pedal pulses in right knee. Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. • Respiratory: Normal respiratory effort. • Neurological: No numbness or tingling in left arm or right leg. No headaches or dizziness.

Results

Numbness in the left arm and right leg is also present.

Assessment

INSTRUCTIONS  The patient will return to clinic at her next scheduled follow up.
